instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no display no chime no backlight  ?
threads.message:
Hi. I have water damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b. replaced damaged by water components, reballed smc, changed new lcd connector, also new lcd cable and also checked memory ram to. Still no picture but is powering up ok.
voltage checked:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.55v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 16.5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.78v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL> - 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL> - 0.75v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.91v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1.15v ( is that a big problem?)

i even reprogramed bios and checked with 3 different lcd screens
Help please guys. i spend 8h on it and still nothing. Hope somebody will help. Is not about money now. is about my head. I will not going leave it until is fixed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no display no chime no backlight  ?
threads.message: 1.15V on CPU means that it is hanging somewhere. If the board would boot that would drop down under 1V. It could be anything from a dead SMC to clock chip or any corroded resistor or trace. Crap under the PCH is possible, anything can cause this behavior.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no display no chime no backlight  ?
threads.message: but is powering up no problem and charging batter so smc must be ok then. board was cleaned twice so is noting bad on it. replaced lots of components to

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no display no chime no backlight  ?
threads.message: Powering up and charging a battery doesn't prove anything at all. It could be anything and everything including the SMC/CPU/PCH. I'm afraid there is no "quick" solution for this.
